title: Princess and Holland America cancel 2020 Gulf of Alaska sailings because of coronavirus pandemic
summary:
SUBSCRIBE NOWIn another blow to Alaska’s struggling economy, Princess Cruises and Holland America Line are canceling Gulf of Alaska sailings for the entire season as the cruise industry grapples with the coronavirus pandemic.
“We know these decisions will have a large adverse economic impact on the state of Alaska which relies on tourism.”Princess announced cancellations of Alaska cruises of the following ships: Coral Princess; Emerald Princess; Golden Princess; Grand Princess; Pacific Princess’ Royal Princess; Ruby Princess; and Star Princess.
Holland America canceled Alaska cruises on the following ships: Maasdam, Volendam, Oosterdam, Noordam and Westerdam.
Nationally, the cruise industry shut down about a month ago amid the rising toll of the new coronavirus that causes the infectious disease known as COVID-19.
“Our outlook for a restart of travel continues to slip further into summer,” Princess spokeswoman Negin Kamali said in an email.

title: Alaskans must unite and demand a coordinated COVID-19 response
summary:
We Alaskans like to think that we are independent and have the steadfast resolve and ability to unite as Alaskans to accomplish any challenge that lies before us.
Widespread, rapid testing will need to become available for Alaskans and for all travelers to Alaska.
Asian countries have been using widespread, rapid testing and cell phone tracing with success, both of which are not available here.
Four months after coronavirus first arrived in the US, there is still no wide spread, rapid testing.
For the first time since WWII, we Alaskans must unite, regardless of party affiliation, with a steadfast resolve to demand our President to lead a coordinated national response using every power available and to the fullest extent possible.

title: Normally a bright spot in the Alaska recession, tourism outlook dims with coronavirus uncertainty
summary:

Though Fairbanks is about 400 miles from the Gulf of Alaska, the tourism industry there is also dependent on cruises.
Businesses and tourism industry advocates are working on their plans now, but the future is still uncertain, she said.

title: Alaska halibut fishermen face a flattened market and fire-sale prices amid coronavirus crisis
summary:
Alaska’s share of the 2020 halibut catch is about 17 million pounds for nearly 2,000 fishermen who own shares of the popular flatfish.
The average statewide price for Alaska halibut in 2019 was $5.30 a pound and $5.35 in 2018.
In 2019, roughly 50 million hatchery salmon, mostly pinks and chums, were caught by Alaska fishermen, valued at $118 million, or 18% of the state’s total salmon harvest value.
For Southeast Alaska, the second-largest hatchery region, fishermen harvested about 6.5 million hatchery fish valued at $32 million, or 37% of the region’s landings value.
Kodiak has the state’s third-highest hatchery production and about 3.4 million hatchery salmon were caught last year, nearly all pinks.

Jean Ann was born June 21, 1936, to Nina Jean and Edgar Elijah Watts in Midland, Texas.

title: Anchorage breaks snow record for New Year’s Day following the warmest Dec. 31 on record
summary:
The snow totals broke the previous record set during the 1963-64 New Year’s, which measured 7.2 inches of snow.
The snowfall came after Anchorage broke the daily record for warmest Dec. 31, with temperatures at Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport measuring 46 degrees.
That broke a previous record that was set in 2018, at 44 degrees for the final day of the year.
Anchorage also saw the third snowiest New Year’s Eve on record, tied with 1959 at 3.3 inches of snow.
But after the clock struck midnight, snow accumulation increased, totaling at 6.2 inches for New Year’s Day and leaping past the previous record of 4.6 inches set in 1964.

summary:

title: Coronavirus leads hundreds of Chinese tourists to cancel Alaska winter trips
summary:
The fast-moving coronavirus outbreak is keeping Chinese travelers at home, leading to hundreds of cancellations during the peak of Alaska’s growing winter tourism season.
The number of Chinese visitors to to the state has grown more than 70% since 2013, according to the Alaska Travel Industry Association.
The state hosted close to 6,000 Chinese travelers in 2019 — which some operators say is likely an undercount, putting the number at more like 10,000.
Alaska tourism groups say they are cautiously watching the coronavirus outbreak unfold, but don’t predict major disturbances to tourism in the long term.
The Alaska Travel Industry Association is “closely tracking developments related to the coronavirus occurrence in China, a growing international market for Alaska tourism,” the organization said in a January statement.

title: 4.2 earthquake rumbles Southeast Alaska
summary:
An earthquake with a reviewed magnitude of 4.2 shook parts of Southeast Alaska on Thursday evening, according to the U.S. Geological Survey .
The quake — which occurred at 5:57 p.m. — was centered off the coast of Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve, west of Elfin Cove and Cross Sound, at a depth of 12.7 miles, according to the Alaska Earthquake Center.
It was reportedly felt as far away as Haines and Juneau.

summary:

On Dec. 22, 1920, the Anchorage City Council unanimously appointed Sturgus as the city’s first chief of police, and he took office on Jan. 1, 1921.
In his Outside lawman tenures, Sturgus’ reputation was much harder, of a lethal shot who killed a criminal in Everett.

title: Alaska’s first PFD raffle will take place Jan. 28
summary:
The first winners of Alaska’s new Permanent Fund dividend raffle will be chosen Jan. 28 in a drawing at a Juneau elementary school, the Alaska Department of Revenue announced this week.
Anne Weske, director of the Permanent Fund Dividend division, said notices about the raffle will be emailed to everyone who chose last year to put a portion of their 2019 dividend into the raffle.
As part of the Permanent Fund dividend application in 2019 and again this year, Alaskans were asked if they wanted to spend a portion of their dividend on raffle entries costing $100 apiece.
The raffle is the brainchild of Sen. Click Bishop, R-Fairbanks, who proposed legislation in 2017 to create it.
The idea is officially a raffle, rather than a state lottery, because winners are guaranteed every year.

title: Anchorage, AK Patch
summary:

The play takes place in a community on Florida’s Gold Coast where wealthy retirees spend their waning years served by workers struggling to make a living.
The play follows four people of diverse backgrounds who are unexpectedly thrown together.
Unlikely friendships form as the four confront the biases that had shaped their lives.

title: With cold, clear skies come sundogs and light pillars, brightening Alaska’s winter
summary:
Besides spicing up the skyscape, sundogs indicate the presence of falling ice crystals, which also form halos around the sun and moon.
The ice crystals falling through the Alaska air, known as diamond dust, also create pillars of light that extend upward from outdoor lights and sometimes downward from the sun.
Sundogs form when ice crystals act as a prism, according to writers of the text Meteorology Today.
The six-sided, platelike ice crystals sometimes fall with their flat surfaces parallel to the Earth.
Just as white light bends when it passes through a glass prism, the ice crystals bend sunlight so it separates into different colors.

title: Cold snap is expected to ease up around Anchorage — but only for a couple days.
summary:
Temperatures early this week are expected to rise as a light snow falls throughout Anchorage, but by Wednesday the weather will be cold and clear again, meteorologists said.
Anchorage will likely warm up into the teens Monday, said National Weather Service meteorologist Shaun Baines, and highs in the 20s are expected Tuesday.
Light snow is expected to fall Monday afternoon and evening and again Tuesday night.
The weather system is moving in from the east and expected to drop 1 to 3 inches of fresh snow in Anchorage.
The Mat-Su area is expected to see lighter snow than Anchorage, with only 1 to 2 inches falling by Tuesday, Baines said.

title: Bill lowering Alaska Pioneer Home rates has a chance of advancing, lawmaker says
summary:
JUNEAU — With a half-hour of emotional testimony on Monday, Juneau residents urged members of a legislative committee to advance a bill that would partially reverse rate hikes at Alaska’s Pioneer Homes.
Drafted by Rep. Zack Fields, D-Anchorage, the bill would limit rate increases at the Pioneer Homes to no more than inflation, as calculated by the annual adjustment in Social Security payments.
The Pioneer Homes had 443 residents as of the last day of 2019, according to figures provided by the department, and each home continues to have a waiting list for entry.
Luann McVey has two parents considering whether or not to enter the Pioneer Homes.
Brad Rider, who testified in favor of the bill, is among the plaintiffs in a lawsuit seeking to reverse the rate increase.

title: Anchorage’s Campbell Lake, long closed to the public, begins to open up
summary:
Jeff Landfield, editor of the Alaska Landmine, spent much of the day Saturday handing out burgers and hotdogs at a party in the middle of frozen Campbell Lake, possibly the first time such a public event had ever happened on the large lake in South Anchorage.
In September, Landfield and Paxson Woelber reported on the history of the man-made lake and attempts to limit public access to it.
Through their reporting they were able to determine that the public is allowed to recreate on the lake, provided they legally access it.
Landfield then organized a GoFundMe campaign, which raised funds to have a surveyor mark two easements which provide legal access to the lake.
Many of the over 100 people that came to the lake on Saturday used the easements, including Anchorage assembly member John Weddleton, who skied around the lake on a groomed track.

title: Photographer captures stunning aerial images of some of America's largest and busiest airports
summary:
AdvertisementAn Alaska-based photographer has spent the past few years taking incredible aerial photos of some of the largest airports in the United States.
The images were captured by photographer, Toby Harriman, who developed a love for aerial photography and cinematography after taking his first doors-off helicopter flight in 2012.
The images show breathtaking views of airports like San Francisco International Airport, Chicago O'Hare International Airport, Chicago Midway International Airport, San Diego International Airport, Norman Y. Mineta San Jose International Airport and the Los Angeles International Airport.
Harriman's images aren't just limited to the runways and terminals, He also captured aerial views of the unique designs of parking garages and roadways surrounding some of America's busiest airports.
In an interview with the New Atlas, Harriman revealed that the first airport that he ever took aerial photos of was the San Francisco International Airport.

title: Effort to raise Alaska oil taxes hits signature threshold to appear on ballot
summary:
A ballot initiative that would boost taxes on the oil industry in Alaska has met the minimum number of qualifying signatures to appear before voters this year.
The proposed Fair Share Act this week surpassed the required signature threshold of 28,501, according to an Alaska Division of Elections count update.
The “Vote Yes for Alaska’s Fair Share" group said they submitted more than 44,000 signatures to Elections officials in January.
The Fair Share Act is expected to raise oil production taxes by about $1 billion annually.
Opponents say higher taxes will drive away oil companies and kill critical investments needed to boost North Slope oil production.

title: Toksook Bay elder is first person counted in 2020 US census
summary:
TOKSOOK BAY — Lizzie Chimiugak has lived for 90 years in windswept Western Alaska, born to a nomadic family who lived in mud homes and followed where the good hunting and fishing led.
Her home now is an outpost on the Bering Sea, Toksook Bay, and on Tuesday she became the first person counted in the U.S. Census, taken every 10 years to apportion representation in Congress and federal money.
"Elders that were before me, if they didn't die too early, I wouldn't have been the first person counted," Lizzie Chimiugak said, speaking Yup'ik language of Yugtun, with family members serving as interpreters.
“Toksook Bay isn’t the easiest place to get to, and the temperature is cold.
In 1947, Lizzie married George Chimiugak, and they eventually settled in Toksook Bay after the town was founded in 1964 by residents of nearby Nightmute.

title: NASA prepares to launch rocket from Alaska’s Poker Flat range
summary:
A slender NASA vehicle will shoot skyward, carrying a sensitive instrument in an arc 160 miles above northern Alaska.
This will tell scientists something about nitric oxide, which sometimes penetrates lower levels of Earth’s atmosphere, destroying ozone molecules.
As with the last few launches from Poker Flat, a livestream will be available on YouTube.
Since 1996, NASA has sponsored almost all of the rockets launched from Poker Flat.
Technicians from Poker Flat will recover the rocket stages by helicopter after the experiment.

title: Anchorage will still host 2020 Board of Fisheries meeting
summary:
Anchorage will be the location for the Alaska Board of Fisheries 2020 Upper Cook Inlet Finfish meeting.
In an unexpected vote in January, the Alaska Board of Fisheries decided to move the 2020 regulatory meeting from the Kenai Peninsula to Anchorage.
Burkhart said the board should hold another vote on the location of the 2020 meeting location, after providing notice.
At the start of the Arctic-Yukon-Kuskokwim finfish meeting on Tuesday, Jan. 15, Board of Fisheries Chair Reed Morisky announced the board would likely be considering the Upper Cook Inlet meeting location at the end of the meeting.
On Friday, Jan. 18, the board reversed their March 2018 decision with a 4-3 vote, moving the 2020 meeting back to Anchorage.

title: Dunleavy launches lottery plans and more in second State of the State speech
summary:
Mike Dunleavy used his second State of the State address to propose new programs, push for smaller government and boost private-sector business in front of the Alaska Legislature on Monday night, but did not suggest a fix for the state’s expected $1.5 billion deficit.
The governor is facing a campaign to remove him from office but did not mention that effort during his speech.
In Monday’s speech, Dunleavy urged the Legislature to consider his proposed constitutional amendments that would guarantee the Permanent Fund dividend, tighten the state’s spending cap and require voter approval of new taxes.
By the numbersDunleavy delivered his 4,600-word speech in 31 minutes, seven minutes more than his 3,500-word speech in 2019 that needed 24 minutes.

title: US evacuees from China expected to get virus screening in Anchorage during refueling stop
summary:
A chartered jet evacuating Americans from China amid the outbreak of a new and potentially deadly virus is expected to be refueled in Anchorage this week, health officials said Monday.
The airport has had six cargo flights land in Anchorage from Wuhan since the beginning of the month, according to a statement from the airport.
The coronavirus was first documented in Wuhan in late December, with at least 106 deaths and over 4,500 cases reported since then.
In the U.S., there have been five confirmed cases of coronavirus but no deaths.
Providence hospital and others in the area are fully prepared to handle a coronavirus patient, if needed, officials said Monday.

Girls hockey periods are 12 minutes long, meaning Richards averaged one save every 42 seconds of play.

title: Homesteader survives frigid Alaska weather for weeks after cabin burns down

“But I just huddled into that dark cave and I slept,” he told troopers during an interview.

After getting a shower and warm food from McDonald’s, Steele said, he would probably spend time with family.

title: Archaeological sites show how people lived in a part of the Brooks Range known for extreme weather

Howard Pass, a rock-stubbled tundra plateau in the western Brooks Range, is one of the lowest points in the mountains that arc across northern Alaska.
Scientists who have visited the lonely spot say Howard Pass is noteworthy for two reasons — it features some of Alaska’s most extreme weather and, curiously, the area has an abundance of archaeological sites.
Jeff Rasic is an archaeologist for the National Park Service who has sifted through wet soil near Howard Pass.
Howard Pass was not so quiet over the past 11,000 years.

Ballots from the Alaska Democratic presidential primary sitting at the party’s counting facility Saturday.

summary:
N95 Respirator (Photo from U.S. Food and Drug Administration)An Alaskan is facing thousands of dollars in fines for alleged price gouging on N95 masks, which are used as personal protective equipment against the coronavirus.
According to a civil complaint filed on Wednesday, Juan Lyle Aune of Anchorage started purchasing packs of N-95 masks in late February as concern about the coronavirus in Alaska started to spread.
He later sold them on eBay and Amazon at over four times their purchase price.
Aune allegedly sold over 600 masks between at prices as high as $90, over four times more than the price he paid at purchase.
Aune faces fines from $1,000 to $25,000 for each time he advertised the masks online, which the complaint alleges happened at least three times.

“Always sounds like it’s coming from the direction of the Eagle River Visitors Center,” she wrote on the Facebook page.

title: Fire in Midtown Anchorage apartment building damages multiple units
summary:
A fire in a Midtown Anchorage apartment just before noon Thursday damaged four units within the eight-plex, a fire official said.
One person in an adjacent unit was transported to a hospital as a precaution after she inhaled smoke, said Brian Dean, an Anchorage fire marshal.
The fire was mostly in the walls and ceiling of two apartments on the second floor, and dropped down to an apartment below.
The four damaged units are uninhabitable, Upchurch said.
But residents in the four undamaged units will be allowed back in once the utilities in the building are turned back on, he said.

title: Passenger in car shot and killed by officers had fired at them during traffic stop, police say
summary:
A person was shot and killed by Anchorage officers early Sunday near the Merrill Field airport after firing at them from a vehicle, police said.
A male passenger in the back seat of the vehicle fired shots at police, Doll said.
The officers returned fire and fatally shot the person, Doll said.
One of the officers was shot in the upper body and has minor injuries, but was protected by his body armor, according to Doll.
On Feb. 5, an officer fired at 31-year-old Logan Parrigin outside a Northway Mall trampoline park.

title: Three candidates vie for HEA District 3 board seat
summary:
The three candidates running for election to represent District 3 on the board are Troy Jones, Pete Kinneen and incumbent board member Eugene “Jim” Levine.
Levine was an HEA board member from 2009-14, and served again from 2016 to present.
A project manager with Jay-Brandt General Contractors in Homer, Levine also has accreditation for Credentialed Cooperative Director from the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association.
“There’s a huge place for savings if we could produce renewable energy instead and not use gas,” he said.

Census takers started flying out to rural Alaska villages in January to join local hires in questioning residents in person.
This is the first count in which the Census Bureau is encouraging a majority of people to answer the questions online.
In Alaska, census taker Carl Schramm said he's had fun going to rugged territory.
The agency said Friday that the retention rate has been about 90% for hires, who include 172 local census takers, 158 census takers from outside rural Alaska villages and 125 field supervisors.

title: Coronavirus leads hundreds of Chinese tourists to cancel Alaska winter trips
summary:
The fast-moving coronavirus outbreak is keeping Chinese travelers at home, leading to hundreds of cancellations during the peak of Alaska’s growing winter tourism season.
The number of Chinese visitors to to the state has grown more than 70% since 2013, according to the Alaska Travel Industry Association.
The state hosted close to 6,000 Chinese travelers in 2019 — which some operators say is likely an undercount, putting the number at more like 10,000.
Alaska tourism groups say they are cautiously watching the coronavirus outbreak unfold, but don’t predict major disturbances to tourism in the long term.
The Alaska Travel Industry Association is “closely tracking developments related to the coronavirus occurrence in China, a growing international market for Alaska tourism,” the organization said in a January statement.

title: State urges Alaskans to make plans for coronavirus

Zink said the state is actively monitoring the spread of the disease, which has sickened thousands of people worldwide and caused two deaths in Washington.
On Saturday, the State of Washington declared a state of emergency due to the virus.
Zink said the disease has not been detected in Alaska, but it’s important Alaskans prepare for the possibility it may arrive here.
On Friday, the State of Alaska released a fact sheet advising Alaskans about how to prepare for the virus.

And we notified the airport police because warrants were on file, just in case Mr. Wagner would have changed his mind.

title: With cold, clear skies come sundogs and light pillars, brightening Alaska’s winter
summary:
Besides spicing up the skyscape, sundogs indicate the presence of falling ice crystals, which also form halos around the sun and moon.
The ice crystals falling through the Alaska air, known as diamond dust, also create pillars of light that extend upward from outdoor lights and sometimes downward from the sun.
Sundogs form when ice crystals act as a prism, according to writers of the text Meteorology Today.
The six-sided, platelike ice crystals sometimes fall with their flat surfaces parallel to the Earth.
Just as white light bends when it passes through a glass prism, the ice crystals bend sunlight so it separates into different colors.

title: I recovered from the coronavirus. But I’m still living with its effects.
summary:
I tested positive for the coronavirus on Feb. 7 while I was quarantined on the Diamond Princess cruise ship.
Still, I was trapped even after my symptoms passed because, to be cleared and discharged, I needed negative results on two consecutive nasopharyngeal coronavirus tests performed 24 hours apart.
It took three weeks for me to get my first partial negative result (nasal positive, throat negative).
For the 28 days we were apart, I survived by texting, calling and FaceTiming him from my hospital room.
I am acutely aware of the impact of losing certain freedoms for the month I was trapped in a small hospital room.

title: Bodies recovered from Southwest Alaska plane crash that killed 4 passengers and pilot

The Yute Commuter Service plane’s pilot and four passengers died in the crash 12 miles south of Tuntutuliak, troopers said Thursday night.
Frigid wind chills Friday on the Southwest Alaska tundra had previously blocked attempts to reach the wreckage, troopers said.
The National Weather Service doesn’t have an observation station in or near Tuntutuliak, said Shaun Baines, a meteorologist with the weather service in Anchorage.
Similar conditions were observed at multiple weather service stations around the Kuskokwim Delta on Thursday, Baines said.

summary:

The snowfall was expected to taper off Wednesday afternoon, with another inch expected, said Jason Ahsenmacher, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service in Anchorage.
He said the west side, where the weather service is based, had received 1.7 inches of snow by around 9 a.m., though other parts of the city likely had more accumulation.
Flurries might still fall tonight in the Anchorage area, with the temperature expected to drop into the single digits Thursday and Friday.
Not including today’s snowfall, Anchorage has received 46.6 inches of snow this season, below the average for the date of 53.9 inches, Ahsenmacher said.

title: How COVID-19 is impacting Anchorage’s small business — and what you can do

title: A brief history of toilet paper in Anchorage
summary:
Visit any Anchorage store right now, and the toilet paper aisle is empty, cleared by residents stocking up amidst coronavirus fears.
The history of commercial toilet paper in America dates back to 1857, when a New Jersey company offered sheets of aloe-soaked paper described as “Therapeutic Paper” in 500 count boxes.
In 1916, Pilger’s General Store advertised three rolls of toilet paper for 25 cents, roughly equal to $6 today.
And for that princely price, it likely would have been some of the worst, roughest toilet paper you’ve ever encountered.
For example, some tied long strips of toilet paper to sticks, letting the breeze wave the paper and hopefully scare bears away.

title: Anchorage high temperature Monday was a record
summary:
Anchorage broke a daily temperature record on Monday, hitting a balmy 54 degrees mid-afternoon, according to the National Weather Service.

The coldest Oct. 28 on record in Anchorage reached just 8 degrees, in 2008.
An “atmospheric river” has been pumping warm and moist air from the tropical Pacific Ocean north, bringing record temperatures to Alaska.
Record high temperatures occurred yesterday at five locations across southern Alaska thanks to a surge of warm and humid air originating in the subtropical Pacific.

Anchorage and other cities had record-breaking temperatures in late October and the warm weather continued into November.

Normally, more than 5 inches of snow has fallen in Anchorage by the end of October and about an inch is left over during Halloween, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Michael Kutz.

Temperatures are predicted to stay above normal on Halloween and Kutz said the low will likely hover barely above freezing at 34 to 36 degrees.

title: Middle Alaska begins its transition to a quieter, snow-covered world
summary:
With a whisper, middle Alaska is undergoing its biggest change of the year.
Snow is covering this part of Alaska that gets coldest in winter and warmest in summer, driving it toward the former.
Snow cover encourages colder air temperatures by reflecting the sun’s rays, not letting the dusky ground absorb warmth.
With all the warmth-driven changes to Alaska in the news, this right-on-time snow coverage is comforting, even though we tend to find most changes uncomfortable.
The cooling power of a suddenly white world is best felt in a year like 1992, when a foot of snow fell on Fairbanks in mid-September.

title: 2 men accused in shootings on Anchorage school grounds now face federal weapons charges
summary:

Laquinton Tyrone Dashawn Robbins, 27, is accused of shooting another man in the neck during an argument at Denali Montessori last October.
The shooting happened shortly after classes started that day, and the school went into lockdown.
In a separate case, John-Rexie Lagman, 22, is accused of shooting a 16-year-old boy he was fighting with at Williwaw Elementary School in early July 2019.

title: A warmer winter with more precipitation is in the forecast for Alaska
summary:

title: Shaky ground: A year after the 7.1 earthquake in Southcentral Alaska

title: Rock slides prompt intermittent closures of Seward Highway south of Anchorage
summary:

title: Alaska’s 2019 salmon season by the numbers
summary:
Alaska’s 2019 salmon season was worth $657.6 million to fishermen, a 10% increase from the 2018 fishery.

title: They shared a passion for reducing plastic waste. Now these two Anchorage women are opening a bulk-goods ‘refillery’ store.
summary:

title: Anchorage breaks 31-year-old daily temperature record Saturday

title: Feeling SAD? Seasonal affective disorder rears its yearly head in Alaska.
summary:
Symptoms of seasonal affective disorder and the less severe “winter blues” start in late fall or early winter and resolve when the sun comes back in spring, according to Lindquist.
Lindquist said it’s common for people with SAD to be haunted by lethargy, cravings, lack of sleep and dark thoughts throughout winter.
People who show SAD symptoms might get too much sleep or too little, Lindquist said.
It’s also possible that during the dark winter months, people start producing too much melatonin, a chemical in the body that causes drowsiness.
She talked with her doctor when her SAD symptoms grew worse.

title: Warmer weather brings rain to Anchorage before temperatures drop again midweek
summary:
Temperatures in Anchorage are expected to rise early in the week, bringing some rain, before the week closes with subzero temperatures and icy roads, meteorologists say.
A mix of snow and rain was expected Monday, said National Weather Service meteorologist Michael Kutz.
Anchorage is expected to reach temperatures in the high 30s on Tuesday, although Bartos said snow is expected late Tuesday night and into Wednesday morning.
He said the high temperature in Anchorage on Thursday is expected to be 22 degrees and Friday only 10 degrees.
The warm weather early in the week will melt some of the snow left from a Christmas Eve storm, Kutz said.

It’s not uncommon for vehicles to crash into power poles or equipment, Hasquet said, but the extent of damage that came from this crash is rare.

title: Finding light in the darkness
summary:
Except for 23 minutes of the first session with our holiday concert music, it’s been dark outside for all of our rehearsals since mid-October.
Each time there’s been new snow, we fool ourselves into thinking maybe this will be the time it sticks for good.
This can be a cold, dark world if we let it be that way, and making it a brighter one takes work — lots of it.
All that better world requires is that we give it more light, warmth and love.
But we’ll have two whole seconds more light that day than the one before.
